instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SD Card slot not working
threads.message:
Got a MacBook Pro 15" 2010 yesterday, I was informed that the USB ports where dead.
There is no water damage as far as I can tell and the previous owner said he probably overloaded the USB ports with USB hubs.

I have got both USB ports working again, both L4605 and L4610 where open and got replaced.

Mounted the MacBook back together to find that the SD Card slot was dead.

I have done a physical inspection and everything seems fine.

<CHIP>U3500</CHIP> gets powered, I have 3.3V all the way.

On <TRANSISTOR>Q3500</TRANSISTOR> i get 3,2V on Pin 2 and 0V on pin 5, I don't know what these are suppose to be.

On Y3500 i get 1,5V on each side

What do I check for next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SD Card slot not working
threads.message: It's usually the slot, check if <SIGNAL>SD_CD_L</SIGNAL> goes low when you insert a card. But why bother, they did not complain about it so they are not using it. Not your problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SD Card slot not working
threads.message:
You are right, after trying several times the card suddenly popped up, so probably just a dirty slot. I bought this one to repair and sell, and if there are any defects its going to affect the value considerably.

Thank you.
